reviewText: PARDON US, Laurel & Hardy's first feature-length comedy, puts them behind bars for making and selling moonshine. Stan has a loose tooth that buzzes, which causes Ollie some grief. They escape during a prison riot and take disguises as black field hands.In this part of the story, Ollie gets to show off his golden singing voice and Stan does a music hall-style soft shoe before they're captured and returned to "stir."Although now considered very politically incorrect, "Pardon Us" is a classic Hal Roach comedy in which the producer (Roach) and director (Parrott) cameo as parading convicts..Parenthetical number preceding title ia a 1 to 10 IMDb viewer poll rating.(7.0) Pardon Us (1931) - Stan Laurel/Oliver Hardy/June Marlowe/Wilfred Lucas/James Finlayson/Walter Long/Tiny Sandford (uncredited: Hal Roach/James Parrott/Leo White)
summary: "When are you going to get that tooth fixed? Every time you speak you make a funny noise. It sounds like a pipe organ."
Title: N/A

reviewText: The majority of American Laurel & Hardy fans have first seen this feature in a grainy copy of a 55-minute American release that Blackhawk sold for years. When first released, the Hal Roach Studios was releasing alternate editions of their comedies to the foreign markets, usually in longer versions, with the stars themselves speaking the translated dialogue. Historians have found evidence of at least four or five variants of "Pardon Us," including an extended version of "Pardon Us" that is the content of this DVD release. This appears to be the British release version with the American titles retained (in Britain this was "Gaol Birds").In terms of structure, longer is not necessarily better. The movie is still what Laurel called a "3-story building on a 1-story foundation." It seems like three short subjects strung together with an arbitrary climax tossed into the final 10 minutes to wrap things up. However, many scenes in this release are longer, particularly the middle sequence on the cotton farm. The added minutes help the individual scenes, relieving the choppiness that has always seemed characteristic of this feature. And while the cotton farm scene slows the feature to a halt, the singing of the Etude Ethiopian Chorus, coupled with Stan & Ollie's song and dance routines, are a pleasant diversion, in spite of the dated imagery.The overall pictoral quality on this release is about a 1000% improvement over the film prints I grew up with, but apart from the overall quality of the feature, for which I'm grateful, this disk is very lean. There are no chapter stops, no chapters of publicity material, no chapters of alternate scenes, some of which still exist. It would have been instructive to have the leaner American release on this or a second disk for sake of comparison. But like too many other American releases of Laurel & Hardy (and Little Rascals) comedies, we're getting the bare bones and little else.But for the Laurel & Hardy fan, this movie is essential viewing. I hope it sells well enough to give the copyright owners incentive to be more ambitious with future releases.
summary: A Little More is Better than Nothing More

reviewText: Great Laurel and Hardy film.Stan and Ollie get sent to the Big House for selling a cop a bottle of beer during Prohibition.(Stan thought he was a street car operator)Once in prison the boys have their troubles with the warden(Wilfred Lucus),Stans loose tooth that buzzes and sounds like hes giving people the raseberry,and head convict,The Tiger(Walter Long)planning a mass escape.Very Funny scene when the boys go to the prison school and have their troubles with the teacher(James Finlayson)Teacher,Whats a blizzard?Stan,The inside of a buzzard.Keep an eye out for Hal Roach and James Parrot(Bits)

reviewText: I bought this video basically for the beautiful rendition of "Lazy Moon" done by Oliver Hardy. This was Stan and Ollie's first full length film done around 1930. It does have an actual plot and many of the duo's gags but there is a deeper and darker historic value here. The scenes of "Darkies" and "Pickaninnies" in the cotton fields are terribly racist and show the lasting effects of the Civil War even 60 years after. It also shows the ignorance, even if excused by innocence, of filmmakers of the time. I can't blame Laurel and Hardy for their films and actions were accepted, applauded, and enjoyed by the filmgoing public. I've shown some scenes to my students who are appropriately appauled, thank goodness! Of course, it brings the question of "Why?" and it may lead to a question of what form Racism takes today.
summary: Laurel, Hardy, Lazy Moon , and Racism

reviewText: L&H;'s Pardon Us was originally conceived as a typical 2 reel 20 minute short feature by Hal Roach studios, a spoof of MGM's The Big House.  Hal Roach had requested the use of MGM's prison set - MGM was the distributing agent for all of Hal Roach's product in 1931, back when MGM owned and operated all of their own Loews theaters - but for whatever reason, MGM refused.  Hal Roach, being the type A and stubborn personality that he was decided to build his own prison set, yet to recoup the costs of the massive set he needed to expand Pardon Us into a full length feature, which commanded a higher premium from MGM.And therein lies the main problem with Pardon Us - it plays like a 20 minute episode with WAY too much padding in order to expand it to 64 minutes - 7 reels.  To compound the problem, this DVD does not come with individual chapters - the whole movie is one big chapter, so the viewer doesn't have the option of breaking the movie up into smaller portions for better digestion.  L&H;'s humor can get old after about 20 minutes, so to watch the whole 64 minute movie in one sitting can be tedious and tiresome.L&H; had the same problem with their second full length feature Pack Up Your Troubles (1932), but by their third, Sons of the Desert (1933), they seem to have gotten the formula right.The print itself used in the DVD has NOT been digitized nor remastered, but is still a relatively clean print for a 77 year old film.  I don't suppose that there would be enough of a market for this DVD to support the costs involved with full restoration.  But as a L&H; fan, I'll take what I can get.In interviews, Stan Laurel often stated that the pacing of their sound era comedy films were deliberately slow to accomodate laughing audiences without drowning out dialogue in large movie theaters - the only medium their films were shown in during the late 1920s - mid 30s.  Stan also stated that he would have loved to have re-edited the L&H; films for television to shorten the long dead pauses and lengthy reaction shots between dialogue and/or physical stunts (Stanley Laurel died in 1965, so he had viewed their work often on TV before his death).  Furthermore, Stan regreted that L&H; ever made any full length features to begin with.  He acknowledged that L&H;'s humor works best in 20 minute short features.  I tend to agree.L&H; comedy is not like the faster pace of Columbia's The 3 Stooges - it's slow, deliberate, avoided cheap one liners, and has that warm Hal Roach charm.  Also, I really enjoy the background music from Leroy Shields and Marvin Hatley that were used in most of Hal Roach's product - more commonly known as "Little Rascals music" by today's audiences unfamiliar with other Hal Roach releases.For the price of this DVD (worth about 4 gallons of gasoline) it's a good value for L&H; fans.  For those unfamiliar with L&H; product, it may be interesting and, in some spots, funny viewing.  Not the LOL type of humor, but a warm savoring with a few chuckles thrown in.

reviewText: Like another reviewer I'll take what I can get. Picture quality is very good on this dvd considering the movie's age. But why are there at least no chapter stops? Also I wonder are we getting the full uncut movie on this disc? I don't think so. The beginning of the movie raises this question immediately. Stan & Ollie are seen outside the malt & hops shop. They're discussing how many ingredients to buy & how much beer they can make with the cash they have. Stan says they can't drink that much but Ollie says they'll sell the rest. The next scene shows the boys in prison uniforms about to face the warden. Ollie is mad at Stan for selling a bottle of beer to a cop! Was a scene of Stan selling beer to a cop filmed & then cut? Obviously so! I have a number of Laurel & Hardy books. A few of them suggest some other scenes being cut as well. On the plus side the gags with Stan's bad tooth are very funny. The escape scene with Stan & Ollie in blackface is great too & handled nicely. Overall a very enjoyable film. Hope we get a few extras next time. For now I'll enjoy this copy again & again. Hope you do too.

reviewText: It's kinda pointless to review Laurel and Hardy, except to say that this is the full 64 minutes of this feature, instead of the shortened version we used to get in the bad old days.So, I'll review the disc. This is made by a small company, so it is on a DVD-R, but it is the only way you can get this movie on a DVD made for North America! (Foreign DVDs play at the wrong speed.) The film print they used is a good one, and it's a nice transfer to digital. Plus, the sound is full and rich. No need to shy away just because it's a small company that made it! This is worth it.

reviewText: Laurel & Hardy's first starring feature film ranks as one of their best. The boys have always fared best on stories with minimal plotting. No banal romantic subplots or musical numbers to intrude here; just pure Laurel & Hardy.And the story idea is brilliant: Where else could Stan & Ollie create the most trouble? Why, in jail, of course! The running gag with Stan's loose tooth giving everyone the rasberry is a hoot. And the part with Stan & Ollie hiding away on a cotton farm (complete with "black face" disguises) after escaping prison is utterly charming. Not only is it presented with no painful Negro stereotypes (unlike those embarrassingly on display in the Marx Brothers' "Day At The Races"), but it showcases Babe's beautiful singing voice, so natural & pleasant (with some eccentric dancing from Stan, too).The DVD format has no extras--not even the usual scene selection menu--but no matter; this is a movie you can watch again & again. It's another stellar example of Stan & Ollie's memorable, disastrous encounters with public authorities...and another example of why they were such a great comedy team.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Pardon Us" gets a bad rap from several critics and historians who consider the film incredibly padded. In actuality, Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy's first feature-length comedy holds up among their better efforts while retaining the hilarious spirit of the Hal Roach two-reelers. A 1931 prison spoof, "Pardon Us" benefits from its increased budget (the penitentiary sets are impressive), a fine supporting cast and some charming musical numbers - particularly Ollie's rendition of "Lazy Moon." The scene where Stan and Ollie maintain a cell-bound conversation in complete darkness has a bleak quality reminiscent of Samuel Beckett. As the thuggish "Tiger," Walter Hall remains the quintessential L&H heavy. Though it's great to have the pre-release version, this DVD should have included the final theatrical cut.
summary: Stan and Ollie's Hilarious Feature Debut
